title: mum allergic baby left covered
story: Mum allergic to her own baby left covered in agonising blisters and weltsA mew mum who developed agonising blisters all over her body discovered she had a rare allergy to her own baby, making it painful to hold her new son called BarneyShe developed a burning, itchy rash all over her body while pregnant Image: Kennedy News Ewa Jones PhotographyByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features EditorRebecca Cooley:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA mum has told how she suffered an incredibly rare aposallergic reactionapos – to her own baby. Fiona Hooker, , developed an itchy rash on her stomach at  weeks pregnant, while carrying her son Barney. Doctors initially offered her steroid creams to combat the itch - but she was left with incredibly painful blisters after giving birth that made it painful to hold her baby. Fiona, who found herself covered agonising blisters and welts, was stunned to discover that she was aposallergicapos to her own BABY. She first noticed itchy red areas on her stomach while pregnant, which felt like aposnettle stingsapos but got progressively worse.After suffering through the remainder of her pregnancy covered in aposunbearable red itchy plaquesapos on her skin, the -year-old says the condition aposexplodedapos once she gave birth.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Doctors diagnosed her with the rare autoimmune pregnancy condition Pemphigoid Gestationis - and said a reaction to a gene in her sonaposs DNA probably caused her immune system to attack her own skin.Fiona said: The pregnancy from  to  weeks was quite hard because my stomach was on fire and obviously I was quite big and had a toddler as well.When I was in labour I didnapost feel a thing, I looked horrendous but it wasnapost itchy at all. But the postpartum bit when it exploded into blisters on my tummy, chest, arms and legs - everywhere you would hold a baby - that was quite dficult. When I was diagnosed I was shocked because itaposs so rare - I was hoping theyaposd got it wrong and it was something . But when it started blistering we knew it was that because thataposs what dferentiates it from other pregnancy rashes. They think it might be to do with the baby - something in the fatheraposs DNA triggers the placenta to start attacking a protein which is also in the skin, so my body was attacking my skin.  My son must have a gene from his dad that my daughter got me from instead because I didnapost have it with my first pregnancy. The hypnobirthing teacher has now shared shocking photos of her rash-ravaged stomach and blistered limbs in a bid to raise awareness of the rare condition, which only affects one in , women. Fiona, from Basingstoke, Hampshire, said: I got a few tiny, really itchy marks around my belly button that felt like nettle stings. I went to the doctors after a few days because it was getting more and more itchy and unbearable. They gave me some steroid creams which didnapost really touch it and it was getting bigger - my belly was covered in red, itchy plaques. It was the third GP I went to see that said it looked like the condition Pemphigoid Gestationis and he referred me to a dermatologist who gave me the strongest steroid cream you can get. It was like I was allergic to my own baby. By  weeks I took myself to AE because I couldnapost bear it and nothing was touching it and they gave me four days of oral steroids which really helped it calm down. But two days before I was due to give birth it started to get unbearable again and  hours after Iaposd given birth it just exploded and turned into blisters. If I scratched it, it felt good and temporarily took the itch away but obviously I was removing the blisters and skin so then I was left with raw, really painful skin and the blisters just came back on top of that. It hurt a lot to even hold my son so I wasnapost really able to enjoy the newborn stage because of it. Fiona was initially prescribed a steroid cream by her GP and referred to a dermatologist. But she ed to the dermatologist multiple times with aposunbearableapos itchiness and pain and was prescribed stronger steroid creams and some oral steroids.  After giving birth to her son Barney, now seven months, on June th, her skin aposexplodedapos into blisters that covered her stomach, thighs, arms and chest. A blood test to check Fionaaposs antibody levels confirmed doctorsapos suspicions and she was diagnosed with Pemphigoid Gestationis on June th. The dermatologist at Basingstoke and North Hampshire Hospital then started her on a strong dose of oral steroids in a desperate bid to get the excruciating condition under control. The mum then spent the next six months slowly working her way down the dferent strengths of oral steroids until she could be weaned off them, just before Christmas. She says the itchy plaques, blisters and scarring from the extreme reaction have finally subsided, although she still occasionally has to use steroid creams and may suffer minor flare-ups for the rest of her le. Knowing sufferers of the condition are likely to develop it again in further pregnancies, the hypnobirthing teacher and her husband Warren Hooker, , have decided to not have any more children. Fiona said: Because Iaposm quite recently off the steroids, every now and again I get a bit itchy and have to use a bit of steroid cream, so I think my body is still getting over it. A lot of people have to have immunosuppressive therapies to get off the steroids and get the condition under control so Iaposm quite lucky. Once itaposs triggered itaposs made worse by certain hormones - oestrogen mainly - so each menstrual cycle I may get a little flare but not enough to need any steroids. So I may have some symptoms of it forever but not as bad as before. Itaposs put me off being pregnant again especially because the research says it will come on earlier and worse and I donapost think I could do that again even with steroids. Princess Dianaaposs unfinished work in the fight against HIV.Harry, speaking from Calornia, joined his friend ex-Wales rugby captain, Gareth Thomas, for an in-depth -minute video call to mark National HIV Testing Week.In the call, he described himself as “a typical guy” who just wants to “fix things”, and said he feels an “obligation” to try to continue Dianaaposs bid to remove the stigma surrounding the illness. The call kicked off with Harry and Gareth greeting each other with the phrase “Hello bud. How you doing ”, with the prince later joking that the former sportsman was “way older” than him.  Gareth chuckled and responded by flexing one of his tattooed biceps and telling Harry: “I’ve got bigger guns than you, bud,” prompting Harry to laugh and mimic him by saying, “Oh, bigger guns”. Asked what made him so passionate about advocating for HIV, Harry said: “Once you get to meet people and you see the suffering around the world, I certainly can’t turn my back on that. “Then add in the fact that my mum’s work was unfinished, I feel obligated to try and continue that as much as possible. Click here to sign up. “I could never fill her shoes, especially in this particular space, but because of what she did and what she stood for and how vocal she was about this issue… it’s a converging of all these dferent pieces. “There’s a way out of it, andthere’s a way out of it and we know there’s a solution, I’m like a typical guy. I just want to help fix things.” Diana, who died following a car crash in , changed the global perception of HIV and Aids, raising awareness of the condition and supporting hospices. In the late s, when many still believed the disease could be contracted through casual contact, she sat by the sickbed of a man with Aids and held his hand. Harry described how the virus used to be a death sentence, but was now a “manageable disease”. He praised his mother’s empathy and curiosity, and said: “What my mum did and so many other people did at that time was to smash that wall down, and kick the door open and say, ‘No, when people are suffering, then we need to learn more’.  “I’ve seen a huge change. People are able and happy to talk about HIV so much more openly, but the stigma still exists and therefore the testing is still a problem.” Former Wales full-back Gareth, who revealed he was HIV positive in , said: “It wouldn’t be scaryyou understood what living with HIV in  is.”Sharing his daily medical routine with Harry, he said: “At am, every single day, my alarm goes off. “I take my HIV medication which is one tablet, and I feel that my day then begins.” Gareth, who came out as the first openly gay rugby union player in , said it was a daunting experience to walk into a sexual health clinic, but he said it was so much easier to test now, in the privacy of your own home, or at drop-in clinics where there are people to talk to. He added: “The sooner you find outyou’re positive then the sooner you can start treatment. If you leave it too late, then it can have circumstances that are irreplaceable, irreparable.”Tackle HIV, a campaign led by Gareth Thomas in partnership with ViiV Healthcare and the Terrence Higgins Trust, aims to tackle stigma and misunderstanding around HIV. story: Pupils mum defends teacher who slept with her child behind girlfriends backRoss Spittal was living with his partner Kim Smyth while he was sleeping with a sixth former, only for the teachers girlfriend to find more than  emails between the pairRoss Spittal began a romantic relationship with the -year-old pupil in ByDuncan GormanMilo BoydNews Reporter:,  Feb  A mum has argued a teacher shouldnapost be struck off after he slept with her child.Ross Spittal admitted having sex with the sixth former on at least two occasions at his home in  while working as a maths teacher at Inveralmond High School in West Lothian.The -year-old was living with his partner at the time, Kim Smyth, , who found over  emails between the pair on a computer.Spittal, from Bishopton, Renfrewshire, was suspended from his job after his relationship with the -year-old pupil was outed. He has since been fighting to remain on the teaching register, arguing he is still fit to be in the classroom.  Today it was revealed that the mother of the pupil has ridden to his rescue, arguing that he should be able to keep teaching and that he was in a stable relationship with her child. In a testimonial to The General Teaching Council for Scotlandaposs  she wrote: He has shown credibility in his role and professionalism at all times. His encouragement allowed pupils to believe in themselves. She added: She has no concerns about Mr Spittalaposs teacher pupil relationship with Person A and sees them in a stable relationship and has been integrated into their family le. Despite the mumaposs intervention, and following a four day hearing, the teaching regulator decided Spittal will be struck off from the register. Panel chair Alison Reid said: In relation to stage  fitness to teach the aposs findings are that the teacher has fallen signicantly short of the standards that are expected of a registered teacher and is therefore unfit to teach. Section .b of the public services reform order means that the  has to direct that the teacher be removed from the register. The  heard how Spittal first kissed the teen when she stayed behind to help him tidy up iPads in his classroom in April . Emails showed that Spittal sent an email to Pupil A at .pm on an evening in May  askingshe was having chill, fun times. He then asked her to: Talk me through ityou are.  He was outed to the school by his then-girlfriend, Kim Smyth, who found emails, including nude images, between the pair on their shared computer. On Monday, Spittal confirmed he was still in a relationship with the former pupil but admitted that his behaviour back in  was totally inappropriate. He said he was ashamed of his actions but believes he still has a lot to offer to teaching. Spittal, now a delivery courier, said: I think about it everyday while Iaposm sitting in my van about where I could beI hadnapost made stupid mistakes. I made decisions and choices I made in a five to six week period I am ashamed and embarrassed of. I use a traffic light system. Stop, thought and action. I stop and process what is going on around me, I then think and assess my options before proceeding with my choice. My professionalism was called into place, it wonapost happen again, I admit all of the allegations.  Prior to the decision, Presenting Officer Sarah Donnachie argued: Mr Spitall did not act honestly at Inveralmond, he knew what he was doing was wrong and he tried to cover up his actions. Mr Spittal has shown no efficient insight into his actions. He has not fully engaged with his feelings and not been honest with himself in the events that led to the kiss. She continued: Mr. Spittal knew what he was doing was wrong. He only disclosed this to Inveralmond when his ex-partner discovered the relationship. He had been reminded of professional respect on two occasions prior to the kiss. Legal Council for Spitall, Claire Rafferty, said her client had taken steps to ensure this doesnapost happen again. She said: He has been under total remediation for two and half years, showing a passion and commitment to teaching. Iaposm not sure what  a person could do to remediate. I am confident he would make the right decision when faced with dficult circumstances. He has put measures in place to ensuresimilar circumstances would arise he would not repeat his actions. His personality traits make it unlikely there will be a repetition of conduct. Elizabeth Gibb, a chartered occupational psychologist who has been working with Spittal since June , gave evidence in the teacheraposs favour at the hearing. She said: I think he took responsibility for his actions before I met him. He scored lower than most adults on assertiveness. He is fundamentally agreeable and is fundamentally trustworthy and unlikely to use charm. He has now given great consideration to how he acted and he seeked help. He is highly unlikely to bend the rules in the future. Today the  concluded their investigation by issuing Spittal with a removal order. title: race against time save teen
story: Race against time to save teen at centre of court battle over kidney transplantAmy McLennan has now made desperate appeals for a kidney donor to save the le of her son William Verden, , who is currently being kept alive through dialysisWilliam Verden, who suffers from kidney disease, is currently being kept alive through dialysis Image: PAByDouglas Whitbread:,  Feb  A woman whose teenage son suffers from kidney disease is immersed in a court dispute about his treatment and appealing for a donor for a le-saving transplant.Ami McLennan, , from Lancaster, says her son William Verden, , who has autism and is being treated at Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital, is in a race against time.Specialists want a judge to decidethey can stop treating William. Mrs Justice Arbuthnot is due to study Williamaposs case at a trial in the Court of Protection, where issues relating to people who lack the mental capacity to make decisions are considered. The trial is scheduled to take place in Liverpool later this month. The judge considered preliminary hearings at an online hearing on Tuesday.  Lawyers told her that bosses at Manchester University NHS Foundation Trust, who have responsibilities for Williamaposs care, wanted decisions to be made as to whether he should have a kidney transplant and whether le-extending haemodialysis should be continued. The Judge is also expected to consider whether active treatment should be withdrawn. Justice Arbuthnot heard that the withdrawal of treatment would lead to Williamaposs death. Williamaposs mother does not want treatment to end and claims that he doesnapost either. A barrister representing Ms McLennan, Victoria Butler-Cole QC, told Mrs Justice Arbuthnot the teenager had very bad kidney disease and had few treatment options left.He was in a pretty dire situation, she added. With the legal case ongoing the family is now also appealing for potential le-saving donors to come forward and help William, said a spokesman for law firm Irwin Mitchell, which represents Ms McLennan, on Wednesday. If a living donor can be found, William would have the best chance of a kidney transplant being successful. Ms McLennan said tests had shown that relatives were not suitable donors. If any of us could give William one of our kidneys we wouldnapost hesitate for a second to do so, she said.  Itaposs a race against time but finding someone kind enough to donate a kidney would mean the world to us. We know itaposs an incredibly selfless act for someone to agree to and there would be assessments to ensure suitability. Justice Arbuthnot has ruled that William, who lives in Lancaster, could be named in media reports of the case after being told that his mother, Ami McLennan, wanted to make a public appeal for a kidney donor. Williamaposs mother wanted reporters to be allowed to name him in reports of the litigation - a campaign that was supported by a number of journalists. They said Williamaposs plight had been reported before Court of Protection proceedings began - and argued that it would be dficult to report hearings without creating an information jigsaw which would give away his identity. Judges typically rule that patients at the centre of Court of Protection proceedings should not be named in media reports, in line with their human right to respect for privacy and family le. A spokesperson for Manchester University NHS Foundation Trust, which manages the Royal Manchester Children’s Hospital, said: “We recognise that this is a very dficult time for William and his family and we will continue to support them. Our clinicians have worked very hard to enable William’s treatment to take place so far, and he continues to have his haemodialysis, as agreed with his family, subject to any change in his clinical condition. The decision on whether a transplant would be in his best interest is a very complex one, requiring consideration of a range of very dficult issues including signicant risks and the possibility that his transplant would fail, which is why the Court of Protection is being asked to make a decision on the best care for William going forward.”Late last year The Mirror reported on William, an avid golf fan, receiving a lesson from professional golfer Trevor Newsham at Heysham Golf Club in Morecambe.Trevor, , was impressed with his swing saying: “He seemed really bright, taking it on board and hit great shots. title: residents prince andrew drive want
story: Residents on ‘Prince Andrew Drive’ want name changed after sex allegationsResidents on the road want the prince’s name removed from their street signs, as he faces a civil case in the US accused of sexually assaulting Virginia Gufre when she was just Resident Terry Beech, who said the name didnt bother him Image: CASCADE NEWS LTDByAlice Peacock:,  Feb People living on Prince Andrew Drive are insisting the street name should be changed, saying it “isn’t right” that the name stays due to the Duke’s sex allegations. Residents on the road in Telford, Shropshire, want the prince’s name removed from their street signs, as he faces a civil case in the US accused of sexually assaulting Virginia Gufre when she was just . This is a claim he has continued to vehemently deny. Virginia Giuffre has said she was trafficked by disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, Andrewaposs friend and a convicted sex offender, to have sex with the royal when she was a minor under US law. Ms Giuffre, now , claims she was forced to have sex with the Queen’s son three times between  and , in New York, London, and on Epstein’s private Carribean island.  She has now filed a battery and infliction of emotional distress lawsuit against the prince, who continues to deny all allegations made against him. In light of the civil sex abuse case, a resident on Prince Andrew Drive told the Shropshire Star that they were considering writing to Council to demand his name is removed. The local, who wished to remain anonymous, said it’s “not right that it’s named after him”. Weaposve been thinking about writing to them, they said. Another local doubled down on the suggestion a change was in order, but suggested the replacement name should keep the royal theme. They said the street could instead be named after one of the Cambridge children, taking the name either Prince George, Prince Louis or Princess Charlotte. Mentioning another nearby street, Sussex Close, they said they wouldnapost want to live there either. However, residents Terry and Kim Beech believe the name should stay the same.Terry said he didnapost think council should change it because of what had happened, and claimed it didnapost really bother him. You canapost keep rewriting history, He said. . Itaposs always been Prince Andrew Drive. We donapost agree with what he might have done, but you canapost keep changing things. You canapost erase history.Heaposs still part of the royal family. title: scientists give verdict whether england
story: Scientists give verdict on whether England is REALLY ready to drop Covid isolation rulesExperts raised concerns for the UKs most vulnerable after Boris Johnson announced the governments plans to abandon self isolation rules by February  and Chancellor Rishi Sunak during a visit to the Kent Oncology Centre at Maidstone Hospital in Kent" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Boris-Johnson-visit-to-Kent.jpg" width"" "" It comes amid fresh calls for Met Police to investigate a No  virtual Christmas quiz after a photo emerged of Boris Johnson with an open bottle of bubbly Image: PAByLaura SharmanNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsScientists have revealed whether they agree with Boris Johnson that England really is ready to lt Covid isolation rules. The Prime Minister said on Tuesday that he wants to drop the legal requirement to isolate by the end of February provided the current encouraging trends in the data continue. Experts have voiced concerns that the removal of the remaining restrictions, which also include the ability for councils to close sites where the virus could be spreading, has caused unease for some of those most at risk.It comes as Mr Johnson continues to fight on despite calls from members of his own party for him to resign over alleged Covid lockdown parties. The Partygate scandal has ripped huge holes in Downing Streetaposs ability to claim it stuck to its own rules during the lockdowns, which saw millions come together to save lives and protect the NHS. Phillip Anderson, head of policy at the MS Society, said ending the restrictions will heap yet more worry and confusion on thousands of immunocompromised people. He added: In the face of callous silence from a government that should be focused on protecting them, they could feel forced to further isolate themselves from others, putting their wider health, wellbeing and livelihoods in danger. James Taylor from disability equality charity Scope, said: Scrapping self-isolation will mean that some disabled people will be feeling very anxious and could potentially be placed in situations that could prove deadly. Nobody should be forced to gamble with their lives, and we need the government to explain to disabled people how theyaposll be safe when this decision is introduced. Virologist Dr Stephen Grfin, of the University of Leeds, said the plan is crazy which goes against all the fundamental principles of public health. He told Sky News: It seems that the government has completely abandoned any concern about people becoming infected. Downing Streetaposs plan is expected to set out further information for vulnerable groups but officials also believe cutting edge treatments will also mitigate some of the risks.  Paul Hunter, professor of medicine at the University of East Anglia, said while there were grounds for optimism in the overall data on deaths and hospital admissions, he had concerns about the vulnerable and people who may not have responded as well to the vaccines. There needs to be robust procedures in place to ensure infections in this group are diagnosed early and antivirals are provided within hours of any positive result, he said. Dr Simon Clarke, associate professor in cellular microbiology at the University of Reading said nobody can be certain of the full consequences. If the requirement on infected iniduals to isolate at home is lted as indicated, it will be an experiment which will either be shown to be very brave or very stupid, but nobody knows for sure what the result will be, he said.  Professor Peter Openshaw, who advises the government on Covid through the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group , said he would be very reluctant to suggest this was the end of Covid, adding it was still a very nasty virus.He told BBC Radio aposs The World At One: We donapost know whataposs around the corner, there could be another iant, perhaps based on Delta or something  with higher pathogenicity, which could come back to bite us anytime, and Iaposm pretty sure that next winter weaposre going to see it back.The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: We would never recommend anyone goes to work when they have an infectious disease.  Covid infection levels have risen in three of the four UK nations with only Wales showing a fall, according to figures published on Wednesday.Scotland and Northern Ireland both saw an increase last week in the number of people in private households likely to have coronavirus, according to the Office for National Statistics .England also saw a rise, though the trend here is uncertain, the ONS said. The data show there is still a high prevalence of the virus across the country, with infections remaining well above pre-Christmas levels. Around one in  people in England had Covid in the week to February , or . million people. This up from one in , or . million people, in the week to January . title: shocked brit gets false teeth
story: Shocked Brit gets  teeth in post  years after he vomited them into bin on holidayPaul Bishop, , thought it was a joke when an envelope carrying his missing teeth turned up after he lost them over a decade ago in Benidorm, SpainPaul Bishop couldnt believe it when his  teeth arrived in the post after he lost them  years ago in Benidorm Image: Daily Mirror Andy StenningByDouglas WhitbreadLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Feb |commentsA holidaymaker who lost his  teeth while vomiting into a bin during a night out in Benidorm was shocked when they arrived in the post -  years later. Paul Bishop, , said he thought it was a joke when an envelope carrying his missing teeth, covered in Spanish postmarks, turned up on his door yesterday . The granddad said heaposd last seen the teeth on a night out at the Spanish seaside resort in , where heaposd gone to celebrate a friendaposs th birthday. But towards the end of an all-day drinking session - after heaposd knocked back a pint of cider - heaposd needed to throw up in a bin and had lost the teeth.  Paul, who works for HMRC, said he hadnapost noticed they were gone until he hit the next bar and had later failed to find the gnashers when he searched the bin. He said despite the loss, he carried on the holiday as normal, singing Elvis and eating and drinking with no teeth before replacing them when he ed to the UK. Years later, Spanish authorities recovered the teeth and managed to trace Paul through his DNA, which he had submitted to the British police  years earlier. And when the long-lost  choppers came back through his letterbox on Wednesday, Paul said he couldnapost believe it. He said: When I first saw it, I thought it was some sort of joke, but then I saw the actual letter, which was written in English.  It mentioned the Alicante area - well, thataposs where I was! Then it mentioned the British council, and I thought: aposItaposs genuine, this!apos It read, aposPlease come back to Spain again, but be careful!apos He added: They donapost fit anymore, but theyaposre still in perfect condition. Paul, from Stalybridge, Manchester, said heaposd lost the teeth after spending the whole day drinking with pals on a holiday in Benidorm, in September . He said: Me and a few friends went to Benidorm for a -day holiday, which coincided with my friendaposs th birthday.  We got halfway through a full dayaposs drinking session. It was getting quite late on, about  or  oaposclock, and I was bloated up with lager, so I had a pint of cider. My friends were all drinking lager, so they drank quicker, and when they finished, they said: aposCome on, weaposre going.apos I had half a pint of cider left, so I threw it down in one, but then I thought aposOh, itaposs coming back, this.apos Paul said he knew that downing the high-strength cider was a crucial mistake a few moments later. He continued: As soon as I got out of the pub, there was one of those great big bottle bins, so I just projectile-d it all into the bin. I thought nothing of it, and then went to the next bar. Paul said he only noticed his teeth were missing when a friend pointed it out to him. He said: My friend said: Where are your teeth apos So I thought aposWhat apos  I realised theyaposd gone in the bin. So I went back to the bin looking for them, but I couldnapost see them anywhere. So I wrote them off. I rang my mates in Manchester, and said: aposI need some new teeth when I come back.apos He added: I spent the rest of the holiday with no teeth, singing Elvis with no teeth, eating and drinking with no teeth. Quite hilarious, really. Paul said when he came back to the UK, he got a new set of  teeth and assumed that the old pair were lost forever. But when Spanish authorities came across the gnashers years later in a landfill site, theyaposd identied them as a body part, and under the law, they had tothem to their owner. Paul had been identied through a DNA swab that heaposd given to police fteen years ago. At the time, he said he was called in by the police for an investigation, but was released without charge and later agreed to give a voluntary DNA sample. Mr Bishop says he does not have a criminal record. Spanish authorities and the British council used that biological information to get the teeth to his doorstep yesterday. He said: I opened the letter, and it turned out my teeth went to some landfill, and because itaposs classed as body parts, the Spanish government wonapost allow them to be destroyed. They were put in some storage centre, and a lab technician came across them a couple of months ago, and tried to trace who the owner of the teeth was through DNA. This professor working for this national biometric company in Spain sent me a letter with it and the teeth in a little plastic bag yesterday. He added: I couldnapost believe it -  years ago! title: sick teen who donated more
story: Sick teen who donated more than £, to help boy hed never met beat cancer has diedRhys Langford, , read the story of six-year-old Jacob Jones, a boy from the same town who was fighting a rare cancer called neuroblastoma, and he immediately donated his le savings to him and his familyRhys, whose cancer left him bedridden, passed away this morning Image: Catherine Langford   SWNSByAlice Peacock:,  Feb A terminally ill teen who raised more than £, for a six-year-old fellow cancer sufferer he never met, has died. Rhys Langford, , had osteosarcoma, a cancer which starts in the bones. Over time, the cancer spread to several other areas of his body. When Rhys read the story of Jacob Jones, a boy from the same town who was fighting a rare cancer called neuroblastoma, he immediately donated £, - his le savings - to the six-year-old and his family. The labourer, who worked for a water supplier, also set up an online crowd funder which has since gone viral and raised more than £, for Jacob and his family. Rhys, whose cancer left him bedridden, passed away this morning. Jacobaposs nan Dawn Jones, , paid tribute, saying the family was “deeply upset”. The love, compassion, strength and courage Rhys showed was unbelievable and he will never be forgotten,” she said.Because of his kindness, Jacob will have a better chance of battling with whatever he is faced with now or in the future. We will never be able to show how much Rhys and his family mean to us. We’re overwhelmed by the fundraising by Rhys and we are heartbroken. Our thoughts are with his family. Rhys was a talented athlete before his illness, and at  had become one of the youngest people in the UK to achieve a black belt in the martial art, Krav Maga, at adult grading. He also scaled Snowdon three times and had dreamed of one day going up Ben Nevis. The first sign of a health problem came when Rhys had a sprint race with friends, lost his balance and fell.  Catherine and his dad Paul Langford, , thought he had a groin strain, but Rhys was still limping eight weeks later. He carried on working but reached a point where he was struggling to get out of the lorry. In October , after ious tests, Rhys was tragically diagnosed with osteosarcoma. Experts at Birminghamaposs Royal Orthopaedic Hospital found an cm tumour in his right hip. Rhys had a series of blood transfusions and went through intensive chemotherapy, quickly dropping from st to st lbs. After the  weeks of chemo Rhys stayed in the Royal Orthopaedic for three weeks for an operation to remove all the bone from his kneecap to his right hip.This would mean Rhys would always need two sticks to walk, but the family hoped it would save his le. Up until August , Rhys then underwent another  weeks of chemo, which they initially thought had cured his cancer and he started to get his le back. But in October, a year after his diagnosis, Rhysapos right leg started to swell, growing three times its normal size.  Rhys spent almost a month in ious hospitals being treated for sepsis in the run-up to Christmas until tragically experts found a cancerous mass in his thigh.Although consultants in Birmingham discussed the possibility of a full amputation of the leg, they told the family on January  that Rhys could not be saved.You can donate to Rhysaposs fundraiser for Jacobaposs by visiting the fundraising page,here .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON HospitalsCancer" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: state school pupils put real
story: State school pupils put in real effort during Covid but two-tier system fails themAfter the news that fee-paying schools gamed the system during lockdowns, with children gaining higher grades, Eva Simpson says we need to close the education gap so the Class of  is not penalised furtherA child pictured during an online lesson Image: Getty ImagesopinionByEva Simpson:,  Feb |comments Private school pupils did better than ever in their A-level exams last year, doubling their top grades.That was the least surprising news since the revelation bears do number twos in the woods.An investigation revealed private schools “gamed” the system after the pandemic forced the cancellation of exams. Instead, the awarding of marks was left down to their teachers. And, surprise surprise, children in fee-paying schools scored highest.Research by The Sunday Times showed % of pupils received A*s in , but this soared to almost % in  when teachers gave the grades. In one school alone, North London Collegiate, which charges over £, a year, .% of pupils were awarded A*s, a staggering increase from just .% in . Of course parents who pay for their children’s education want bang for their buck and boy did they get it.  But it’s not just about questionable grade inflation. When the country went into ­lockdown, forcing schools to close, private school pupils switched ­seamlessly to online classes. Children continued to have access to high-quality education and virtual “face to face” lessons with teachers. It should have been the same for all children, but it wasn’t. For many state school kids there often were no lessons with teachers for months. Lesson plans were put online for pupils to ­effectively teach themselves. While in the private sector kids could log in from any number of devices, other ­children, especially those in more deprived parts of the country, were scrabbling for laptops and tablets, ­struggling with wi issues and parents who didn’t have enough data.My fear is this will exacerbate inequality. Education is meant to be the great leveller, but the playing field has never been so unequal.Students with these mega-high grades will get their pick of universities and jobs. There have already been calls for an inquiry. That’s all well and good but what will it solve  Some people have suggested private schools should lose their tax-free status and that money be given to the state school sector. There has to be a way of ensuring the Covid Class of  isn’t penalised any more. I’d like to see a section added to uni and job applications that reveals the level of support, or lack of it, they had in the pandemic, for more context. Because for pupils in state schools, passing under those circumstances should be applauded – and worth far more. It’s time to stop the gap widening any further. in Syria.None of them wouldto the UK.Shamima, , and her year  friends from Bethnal Green Academy were described as straight-A students before they decided to join the caliphate.The trio hit headlines around the world when CCTV images of them walking through metal detectors at the London airport were released in a desperate bid to stop them arriving at their destination.  The teenagers were traveling alone, with Shamima wearing a leopard print scarf, -year- old Amira in a luminous yellow hoody and -year-old Kadiza with a grey checked scarf and jumper. The scarves were seen again in CCTV of the girls at a bus terminal in Istanbul turkey, as they carried their heavy bags through the snow and waited for to board the public transport onward. The police appeal was already too late, the girls had already made it across the border. In the weeks leading up to their disappearance, another girl from their school had made the same journey to Syria to join what they Shamima says she was told was just an Islamic community.  Police had been to their school and had wanted to interview the girls about what they knew, but crucially letters asking their parents permission to speak to them never reached home. Instead of the letters being posted or emailed home, they were given to the girls who simply hid them between pages of a text book in their bags. Now in Syria, the teenagers all married Islamic fighters although the roles they played in the caliphate remain uncertain. Shamima claims she was simply a housewe, while intelligence sources have said she was involved with stitching explosives into suicide vests.Kadiza Sultana was the oldest of the three girls. She had married an American ISIS fighter but in phone calls to her sister in the UK, filmed for ITV News, she said she wanted toto the UK but was scared. Speaking straight after the phone call her sister Halima said: “She sounds very terried. She did get very emotional there as well. It feels…I feel really helpless. What can I do  It’s really hard. I don’t think she’s ever made a choice by herself. That was the first one and a very big one. I just look forward to the next call and that’s what keeps me going.” Kadiza is believed to have died in a Russian airstrike a few weeks later in May , but that has never been independently confirmed. Her familyaposs lawyer, Tasnime Akunjee, told BBC Newsnight they heard a report of her death in Raqqa.He said: The problem with that was the risk factors around leaving are quite terminal also, in thatISIS were able to detect and capture you then their punishment is quite brutal for trying to leave. In the week where she was thinking of these issues a young Austrian girl had been caught trying to leave ISIS territory and was by all reports beaten to death publicly, so given that that was circulated in the region as well as outside - I think Kadiza took that as a bad omen and decided not to take the risk.  Mr Akunjee added: I think she found out pretty quickly that the propaganda doesnapost match up with the reality. Speaking years later Shamima Begum spoke about losing her friend. She said: Her house was bombed. Underground, there was secret stuff going on and a spy had figured out that something was going on and other people got killed as well. At first I was in denial. I thoughtwe died weaposd die together.  Amira Abase had also married an ISIS fighter, Abdullah Elmir an -year-old Australian, who was nicknamed the Ginger Jihadi, because of his ginger hair. He was killed in a drone strike in December . Amira had been communicating with her mum Fetia Hussen back in the UK via social media but the messages suddenly stopped and her mum now believes her daughter is dead too. Although Shamima Begum has claimed Amira is still alive. Shamima herself has since been stripped of her British citizenship in  and become a mother to three children, who have all died during her time out of the UK. She is now selling food parcels she has been given in a detention camp by aid agencies to make enough money for western clothes and hair dye.  She has claimed she wants to stand out from the other women at a detention camp who are still supporting the terrorist organisation, by changing her look.Ms Begum, who has been living in Al-Roj Camp in northeast since her UK citizenship was stripped in , has spoken to ITV News as part of a new podcast series, presented by Global Security Editor Rohit Kachroo.Shamima Begum: The Blame Game podcast looks at whether the authorities made errors that enabled the -year-old to travel to Syria with her friends. She has made messages which have been smuggled out of the camp and sent to a filmmaker. In them she makes clear her despair at being left aposstatelessapos and describes how she has tried to recover from the trauma of losing three babies. story: What is Lassa fever and has it circulated in the UK before  How dangerous it really isTwo people have been diagnosed with Lassa fever in the UK. Here’s everything you need to know about the Ebola-like virus including symptoms and how dangerous it isSevere symptoms of Lassa fever include bleeding from the mouth, nose, vagina or gastrointestinal tract Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByMalvika PadinTrends Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments The UK Health Security Agencyhas confirmed that members of a family who recently ed from west Africa have been infected by Lassa fever.A third relative of the family who live in the East of England is also suspected of having the disease is currently waiting for test results.The Ebola -like virus is an endemic in west Africa, where , to , cases of the disease are estimated each year.There has been no evidence of a further spread beyond three people in the UK so far. But to be on the safe side, here’s everything you need to know about lassa fever, how it spreads and how dangerous it is. What is Lassa fever and how does it spread   Lassa fever is an acute viral haemorrhagic illness caused by Lassa virus. The virus is spread from exposure to food or household items contaminated with the urine or faeces of infected rats. You can also catch it through contact with infected bodily fluids. Dr Sir Michael Jacobs, consultant in infectious diseases at the Royal Free London, said: People living in endemic areas of west Africa with high populations of rodents are most at risk of Lassa fever. Imported cases rarely occur where in the world. He added thatit does spread beyond the endemic areas itaposs usually among high-risk occupations like medical or aid workers. What are the symptoms of Lassa fever  Around % of people infected with Lassa fever show no symptoms. However, some people experience symptoms like fever with aches and pains that can progress to headaches, vomiting and diarrhoea. In certain severe cases, people may have facial swelling, fluid in the lung cavity, bleeding from the mouth, nose, vagina or gastrointestinal tract and low blood pressure.Deafness also occurs in % of patients who survive the disease, but hearing usually s partially after one to three months in half of these cases. According to the World Health Organisation, only % of those infected with the Lassa virus die. How dangerous is Lassa fever and has it spread in the UK before  This is the first time Lassa fever has spread in the UK in over a decade. The disease was found in Britain back in  and there have only been eight previous cases in the country. Dr Susan Hopkins, chief medical adviser at UKHSA, has assured that overall risk to UK public due to Lassa fever is very low. She said: Cases of Lassa fever are rare in the UK and it does not spread easily between people. We are contacting the iniduals who have had close contact with the cases prior to confirmation of their infection, to provide appropriate assessment, support and advice. story: Exclusive: Woman who thought shed never have kids thanks miracle drug for giving her chanceSarah Kay, , spent her teenage years believing it was inevitable that she would be dead in a decade, never mind the possibility of having children - but now shes fit healthy and trying for a babySarah nearly died as a teenager and suffered a total lung collapse at  thanks to her condition Image: CollectByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA woman who spent a decade believing she couldnapost have children wants to meet the makers of a miracle drug which has allowed her to start trying for a baby.Sarah Kay, , was diagnosed with Cystic Fibrosis at the age of four and realised the gravity of what that meant a few years later when she googled her le expectancy at the age of .The first three decades of her le were plagued with hospital visits, infections and the stark reminder that she would probably die before she turned . But now Sarah, from Crewe, Cheshire, is happily married and undergoing IVF to have a baby thanks to a new drug, Kaftrio, approved for use in the UK in June . Now she is on a mission to meet scientists at Vertex - the pharmaceuticals company which created the lechanging treatment - and thank them.Have you got an inspiring story to tell  Email webnews@mirror Sarah said: “I just want to be able to tell them thank you and make them understand what this means.When I was  the topic of pregnancy came up with my doctors.It was very much a case of don’t get pregnant because you’re not well enough to carry a baby. I thought I would never have kids and I started to forget that side of my le. I thought I was ok with it but in hindsight I wasnapost because it’s something I’ve always wanted. I still can’t get my head around that it is a possibility for me now.  Sarah met her now husband, Stephen, in , just as she suffered a total spontaneous pneumothorax where both of her lungs collapsed. For years she had anticipated this near death experience, after she had grown up believing that the cystic fibrosis would kill her before she turned . She said: “I remember googling my le expectancy when I was about . At that time the average le expectancy for someone with cystic fibrosis was  years. “All through my teenage years I rebelled because I just didn’t care, I wanted to live my le and have fun because I thought I’d be dead by .  But that attitude changed for Sarah after meeting the love of her le, and she became determined to beat the cystic fibrosis and live her le with Stephen to the full. Trials for new drug Kaftrio were showing hugely promising results over in America after scientists had created a treatment made up of three parts which helped the body to use the protein enzyme in the proper way to rid cells of this sticky mucus. She said: “When I met my husband everything changed, I wanted to be around for a long time. “I started to think about cystic fibrosis and how it could stop me from having a future with him. I already knew he wanted children because we had been friends previously. I said to himthis is going to go somewhere I need to tell you something. I told him aposI donapost think I can have children and with my health the way it is I can’t see that changingapos.  Since starting on Kaftrio, Sarah has undergone two rounds of IVF but is also trying for a baby naturally. She said: I’m a big kid myself and so is Stephen. We love being around them and having our friends’ kids around so it would mean everything to have one of our own Because of this drug and where my body is at it finally feels like a possibility. “I don’t feel like I have cystic fibrosis any more, I can’t remember the last time that I coughed. I just canapost wait to see Stephenaposs face when I can finally tell him that Iaposm pregnant.Following the NHS bid to secure Kaftrio for patients in the UK, health experts estimate that nine in  people living with Cystic Fibrosis will benefit from this le-transforming drug.NHS chief executive Amanda Pritchard said: “Since NHS staff delivered one of the fastest rollouts of Kaftrio in the world just over a year ago, the lives of thousands of patients with cystic fibrosis have been transformed. “Innovative treatments like Kaftrio are le-changing for patients and their families, and that is why the NHS has done all it can since we secured the deal for Kaftrio to ensure patients benefit as soon as possible. Now Sarah is urging people to help her get the hashtag #SarahMeetsVertex trending in an effort to see her dreams become a reality. Sarah said: “In some ways I feel so lucky to have cystic fibrosis. “When you are in the cystic fibrosis community you meet so many beautul people with this condition and they inspire you in so many ways with their strength. “I have lost incredible friends along the way. “I want to thank these scientists who have made this wonderful treatment for all the people who will come after us, who won’t have to go through what we have been through.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Le expectancyCystic fibrosisPeople" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: You should never drink water from bathroom tapyou live in this type of house, says expertWater experts have revealed that drinking water from the bathroom tap could be dangerous for your health - but it all depends on the plumbing system in your houseGrabbing a drink from the kitchen is better for your healthImage: Getty ImagesByZahna EklundAudience writerMagdalene Dalziel:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments Have you ever been told that you should never drink from the bathroom tap  The answer seems to y wildly between households - and apparently, so does the truth behind the old wivesapos tale. Some of us will have grown up being told by our parents that we should always head to the kitchenwe want a glass of water, but others were raised not knowing the dference and not having to travel all the way downstairs in the middle of the night just to quench our thirst. And according to Glasgow Live, the truth depends on the type of house you live in and where the water in your bathroom comes from.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. So, is it safe to drink tap water from the bathroom  In many older homes, the water you find in your bathroom has usually been stored in a tank in the loft, meaning it isnapost fresh from the mains like that which you get in the kitchen. But the bigger issue is the presence of lead piping in old homes, as this can dissolve into drinking water and can be incredibly dangerous - especially for babies and children.  Water that comes directly from the mains hasnapost had the time to absorb lead from pipes yet, but itaposs a dferent story in the bathroom, where the combination of the lead and the water tank can be detrimental to your health. So, what you really need to know when it comes to drinking water from the bathroom is how old your house is. Modern homes are usually fitted with copper or plastic pipes as the use of lead in piping was phased out in the UK by , so you should be fine to drink from the bathroom tapyour house is up to date. Julie Spinks, from WaterSafe, said in : The plumbing in homes is the responsibility of the homeowner, so we are urging all households to spend a few minutes checkingthey have lead pipes.“To safeguard health we would recommend replacing lead pipes that supply drinking water to bathrooms and kitchens with copper or plastic ones. When should you avoid drinking from the bathroom tap According to The Water Professor, old pipes and water tanks arenapost the only reasons you might want to avoid the temptation to stumble out of bed and head straight for the bathroom.If you make use of filtered water from your kitchen tap to improve the quality of your drinking water, you probably want to steer clear of the bathroom, as this water wonapost be filtered. You should also avoid your bathroom tapyouaposve installed a water softener to prevent you from showering or bathing in hard water. This is because hard water is safe to drink, but the process of softening the water can lead to high levels of sodium in the water from your bathroom. And regardless of which room you get your water from, it should never be from the hot tap. The hot water is often stored in tanks that can be heated and cooled many times and could lead to the growth of bacteria such as legionella - so always choose the cold tap. Ultimately, The Water Professor claims drinking tap water from the bathroom is unlikely to kill you but isnapost the best quality it could be, and the kitchen is a far safer option.Have you got a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum found baby foaming mouth
story: Mum found baby foaming at mouth after leaving him in hot car for  hours as she gambledKaija Millar, , left  month-old Easton in the car for almost five hours while she played bingo and slot machines inside a hotel - before lying to those who came to helpMillar, jailed for three years after pleading guilty to negligently causing serious injury Image: FacebookByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Feb |commentsA mother who found he son foaming at the mouth and convulsing after being trapped in a baking hot car while she gambled has been jailed. Kaija Millar, , left  month-old Easton in the car for almost five hours while she played bingo and slot machines inside a hotel.Millar, jailed for three years after pleading guilty to negligently causing serious injury, parked the car outside the Melbourne hotel in Australia when temperatures had already reached C.As Easton lay strapped in the car, temperatures rose to an agonising .C.An Australian court heard when Millar ed to the car at around pm in the afternoon, he was foaming at the mouth, convulsing and non-responsive. She raced back into the Point Cook Hotel for help, lying to those who came about what had happened. Millar told people inside the hotel her son was suffering from the bushfire smoke haze in the area - further lying to cover her tracks by saying he had only been in the car for two hours with the windows down and air conditioning on. She told paramedics not to tell her husband she had been gambling and claimed she had checked on Easton every two hours, which CCTV footage disproved.Although Easton survived his harrowing ordeal, he has been left with severe disabilities that affect all aspects of his ing, reports News. Judge Felicity Hampel said these disabilities were a direct consequence of Millaraposs actions. She told Millar: This was not a tragic accident. Your son suffered these injuries because you left him unattended and uncared for inside a locked car on a scorching hot day. A reasonable mother.. would have realised her conduct... created a high risk of death or really serious injury.  Millaraposs defence said she former Uber driver had struggled as a first time mum, had experienced post natal depression. They claimed she had a lower than average intellectual ing which impaired her judgement. However, Judge Hampel said Millar knew her actions were unacceptable as she went on to lie to those who came to help. Judge Hampel said jail was the only option to punish Millar. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: lochgilphead composer creates new islay symphony
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThe Royal Scottish National Orchestra has recorded a new symphony written by a Lochgilphead composer who was inspired by the beauty of Islay.The Rinns of Islay, composed by Helen MacKinnon, is a -minute symphony that portrays #a musical journey around the Inner Hebridean island#, which was home to the composer’s grandparents and generations before.Inspired by stories of Islay in her youth, Helen began sketching the work during her composition studies at The University of Glasgow and ed to complete the work nearly  years later.The -minute piece for symphony orchestra was recorded in Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, with American-based PARMA Recordings and GRAMMY-winning producer Brad Michel.Helen, who grew up in Lochgilphead. explained: #It was a privilege to record with Scotland’s national orchestra.#The musicians and conductor, David Watkin, breathed glorious le into the work, which takes us on a musical journey around the island.#Due to Covid, we had a cross-Atlantic recording team, with technology connecting a producer in Boston with a team on the ground in Glasgow. It was a fascinating experience.#The new orchestral work was inspired by Islay’s stunning natural environment, known for its rich terrain and peaty whisky.Five short thematic movements celebrate Islay’s sunrises and coastal shores, while giving a playful nod to the island’s abundant whisky industry.Helen added: #The work centres around The Rinns – a beautul peninsula overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.#My father used to talk about The Rinns of Islay, and as a child, I started to create stories and soundscapes linked to the island.#The work offers a visual, almost cinematic listening experience, with atmospheres and landmarks inspiring the visual imagination.#The work features on a new album Legends and Light Vol. , featuring works by seven composers.While many of the pieces are arranged for orchestral ensembles, listeners will also find the Highland bagpipes and Irish Uilleann pipes featured on the album, offering a deeply rewarding listening experience.Helen is delighted with feedback so far: #I’m thrilled with audiences’ responses to the music.#Listeners have tuned in from across the UK, the USA and as far afield as New Zealand, keeping Scotland on the international map for new music.#

title: heathers treks beinn odhar the dun coloured mountain
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowHeather Thomas-Smith runs Heathery Heights, an outdoor adventure and discovery company based in Lochgilphead, offering guided walking adventures, outdoor activities, training and experiences. She has travelled and trekked throughout the world, walked across Scotland numerous times, climbed many of its peaks and now lives in Argyll amongst the scenery she loves. All her walks can be booked as bespoke guided experiences. www.heatheryheightsPIC:no_a_HeatherClinging to the edge of Argyll are several well-known Munros and Corbetts that share ridgelines, summits or slopes with surrounding counties. Amongst these is Beinn Odhar # its southern slopes lying firmly in the county of Stirling, whilst its summit stands proudly in Argyll.If approached from the west, north or south you could keep your toes in Argyll all day. Unless on a round of Corbetts # there are five here that make a fine challenge # it is easier to approach the Corbett via its gentler slopes from Tyndrum. This also gives the opportunity to explore the adit # access tunnel # and old lead mine on its higher slopes where the mineral vein continuation from Sron nan Colan is exposed. The Beinn Odhar lead mining venture appears to have been a short one but the views once the summit is reached are tremendous.Leaving the car park, cross the A and head left passing the Tyndrum Inn, the Green Welly Stop and cross the bridge.Turn right immediately after crossing the bridge to join the West Highland Waynorthwards, passing the KeyStore.You will need to stay on the WHW for the next .km as it slowly climbs out of Tyndrum with the A on your left and the Crom Allton your right until you reach the bridges over the burn and railway.Cross the bridges and go through the gate at the north end. You will be heading up on to the open hillside to your right.You now have a choice. Either head straight up in a north easterly direction picking your own route on the grassy slopes or veer slightly right back to the Crom Allt to pick up a faint path. If you use the latter, ensure you head upwards at around NN. Either way you will tend to end up on sections of the old mining path as it zigs zags upwards by default due to the natural line of the slope.Once you reach m # after approximately .km depending on how direct your route was # the ground becomes stonier. The adit and mine are higher to your left, northwest, on the crest of the ridgeline, whereas the faint path runs just under this soyou want to explore them it is worth scrabbling up the rocks to have a look. The bottom of the adit starts at around ms.Heading up from the adit and mine # or path # the route flattens out, passing a lochan and the county boundary to your left. Ahead, the final ascent is best tackled by heading northeast then northwest to follow the hill’s natural line. There are no particular dficulties.The summit views are fabulous and an excellent panorama of Beinn Dorain can be had from the steep northern slopes above Coire Luaidh.It is easiest todown the southwestern slopes you ascended, but other possibilities could include some of the neighbouring Corbetts, especially the longer days in summer.Safety in the outdoorsThe described routes and accompanying information are there to be used as a guide and do not replace the use of map and compass and the skills required to use them.Whilst every effort is made to ensure the route is accurate at the time of going to print,  please be aware track and path closures can happen at any time. All walks are undertaken at your own risk.Please continue to adhere to current governement guidelines, exercise responsibly and use appropriate clothing and equipment for your chosen outdoor activity. Inform a contact about your route whereabouts. Don’t forget your phone, snacks, drink, any medication first aid supplies you may need and to check weather conditions. Most walks are dog friendly, but please keep your dog under close control, especially around livestock and wildle. Please follow the Scottish Outdoor Access Code.PICS:Beinn Dorain and the Black Mount hills from Beinn Odhar. no_aHeathersTreks_Beinn Odhar_Beinn Dorain_Black MountMist catches sunlight from the slopes of Beinn Odhar near Tyndrum. no_aHeathersTreks_Beinn Odhar_catchingsun

title: townsend-not-getting-carried-away-england-win
story: A delighted Gregor Townsend hailed his Scotland players after they retained the Calcutta Cup with a - victory over England at BT Murrayfield yesterday.London Irish scrum-half Ben White opened the scoring after good work by Hawick man Darcy Graham then a penalty try followed after England hooker Luke Cowan was sinbinned following a deliberate knock-on.  Finn Russell also converted two penalties and a conversion of the White try.It was the first time since  that Scotland had won back-to-back games in the fixture and the fans celebrated long into the Edinburgh night.The Borders’ man isn’t getting carried away with thoughts of a first Six Nations title though and remembers last year when they failed to build on the victory over England at Twickenham by losing to Wales at Murrayfield.He said: “Last year we started really well, and that showed the confidence the players had from their win at Twickenham. We were - upso how we prepared last year was fine.“It was just how we dealt with situations like not scoring a try in the Wales  at the end of the first half and giving away three penalties in a row to hand momentum back to Wales, then in the second half, not dealing with the red card when we needed to adjust.“Confidence and belief is important, it gives you the ability to adapt and show character, but we have to deliver the detail as well. We can be better than this week, and we believe Wales will be better than they showed this week.“Being tough to beat is really important. It usually defines championship-winning teams, a strong defence in any sport. We know our defence is really entwined with our attack. We’ve got some really dangerous attackers in our team who we want to give the ball to.“Getting both of those sides of the game right is so important. But defence certainly helps you win those tight games.”

title: borderers-one-game-away-world-cup-qualification

title: areas-borders-feel-unsafe
story: Are there areas in the Scottish Borders where you feel unsafe Police officers want to know and  they have launched an -minute survey where participants can place virtual pins on a map to identy dangerous locations.A maximum of three pins can be placed on the map and those taking part will be asked to provide much detail as possible.Locations may be street names, buildings, areas of towns cities, or names of parks and it is important to be specic.Participants are then asked what specically makes them feel less safe in this area and what would make this area feel more safe for them This new service lets the public anonymously tell officers about public places where they have felt or feel unsafe, because of environmental issues, e.g. street lighting, abandoned buildings or vandalism and or because of some behaviours, e.g. being followed or verbally abused.Other questions asked include how safe do you feel in your local area To what extent has your concern about crime in your local area increased or decreased in the last  months What are the police doing well in your local area And is there anything the police could do better to support communities in your local area The survey can be accessed at Police Scotland’s Facebook page.

title: ex-sbc-communications-boss-appears-chase
story: A BORDERS man made an appearance on a popular TV quiz show last week.Mark Wilson, who was the communications and marketing manager at Scottish Borders Council, but now works with the internal communications department with the SQA, was a contestant on ITV’s The Chase on Friday evening.The programme, although filmed in September , was aired on Friday, February  at pm.:A reopens after y recovery operation to remove lorryThe -year-old, who is originally from Peebles, said: “It was all good fun.“It was filmed in September so it was strange watching it back.“It was a good experience.”As the first player up, Mark was asked by host Bradley Walsh what he would dohe won any money. Mark explained that he is a WWE wrestling fan, and would like to see Wrestlemania – a live event – in the USA.:Ten of our favourite photographs from our camera clubIn the ‘Cash-builder’ round, Mark answered seven questions correctly, earning him £, to play with against the Chaser, Anne Hegerty – ‘The Governess’.Although Mark made it back to his team in one piece, for the ‘Race Against the Chaser’ Mark was joined only by fellow contestant Jo.“It was tough with two people,” Mark said. “Anne was on fire.”:Council looks to write off former Borders property company’s £k debtThe duo answered an impressive  questions correctly between the two of them, however their efforts were no match against The Governess who matched their total with more than  seconds to spare.
